stream_context.summary: Kaze reworks a problematic sub-area inside Course 2 (Divine Dino Domain’s temple section), focusing on improving traversal (staircases, vines, safer recovery from water) before doing final art/UV work. He also gives major project-status updates (Course 12 essentially finished, only a few courses left), flags a water-related crash risk due to an outdated step-function, and explains a decomp-specific limitation that forces all level areas to be loaded at once (RAM/loading-time hit).
stream_context.significance_reason: Contains concrete production-status milestones (Course 12 basically done; ~80% overall; only ~3 courses left) plus two interview-relevant technical constraints (water crash due to step-function mismatch; decomp can’t use RoamManager-style per-area loading, costing RAM and loading time).

findings.summary: Course 2’s temple sub-area is being substantially reworked because the previous traversal (an older leaf/ride section) “sucked”; Kaze is shifting it into a more open “platforming playground” with multiple routes, staircases for recovery, and vine/hanging traversal, postponing final visuals until the movement feels good.

Kaze says the project is "just above 80%" complete and that only a few courses remain; he also states he finished Course 12 mostly off-stream, with only remaining polish items like Zeina’s final animations and some sign text.

Late-game course planning is partially locked: Course 13 is planned as a suspenseful “mysterious ice castle” (still needs a boss), Course 14 is a “space arcade,” while Course 15’s concept is still undecided.

Kaze has already started Course 14 and has at least one major area built that he is intentionally not showing on stream, saying it’s being kept secret for a competition/pack (he attributes the request to “Eiza”).

A known stability risk remains: water mechanics have not been migrated to the “new step function,” and the older step functions are “not fully supported anymore,” meaning entering water can still crash the game—so Kaze is cautious about testing water-heavy sections.

Kaze explains why loading times/RAM usage can be worse in the decomp workflow: a legacy tool (RoamManager) could load level areas one-by-one in binary hacks, but it can’t be used with decomp as-is; doing per-area loading in decomp would require linker-script work he hasn’t learned yet, so areas currently load all-at-once, costing RAM.

He blames several testing headaches on the Parallel emulator (frequent updates, poor hotkey responsiveness, issues that don’t reproduce on real N64, and controller problems), implying he relies on other emulators/debug builds and real hardware to validate behavior.

Kaze reiterates he avoids Patreon-exclusive bonuses or distributing certain enhancements because he believes it could increase legal risk with Nintendo, framing it as a deliberate boundary in how he monetizes and shares work.

He live-iterates on YouTube packaging strategy, changing a video title to improve click-through rate and explicitly describes this as “how YouTubers think,” showing how analytics-driven decisions influence his release workflow alongside development.

A long comedic segment centers on Zeina accidentally shaving a bald stripe into Kaze’s hair during a haircut, leading him to hide it under a hat/hood; while mostly banter, it’s a rare candid snapshot of their day-to-day dynamic during crunch.

zeina.summary: Kaze says Course 12 is essentially complete but still depends on “a few more animations from Zeina” plus minor polish (e.g., signs) before it’s ready to ship.
Zeina cut Kaze’s hair and the clipper guard came off, leaving a visible bald line that Kaze hides on stream; the incident becomes an extended bit that also reveals their playful-but-blunt rapport.

findings.summary: Kaze tells AkiDev he recently modified AkiDev’s Chain Chomp code so he could reuse it for a second Chain Chomp in another level, implying ongoing refactors/reuse of community-authored systems as the project expands.
Kaze mentions a separate N64-targeted mod release is timed to happen after SimpleFlips plays it for a competition, indicating creator-ecosystem coordination affects release timing.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: The day where you can play this game will one day come, unless someone murders me. If someone murders me, it was a Nintendo employee.
memorable_quotes.context: Dark-humor aside while discussing the game’s eventual public availability; it reflects his long-running anxiety/jokes about Nintendo legal pressure and the stakes he feels around finishing and releasing.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: I also don’t give out any Patreon bonuses, because that might get me in legal trouble with Nintendo. So I stay away from that.
memorable_quotes.context: A clear statement of his monetization/legal strategy boundaries—useful for documentary framing around risk management.

key_stories.title: Rebuilding Course 2’s temple sub-area around “platforming first”
key_stories.summary: Kaze revisits an older section of Divine Dino Domain because the original traversal flow felt bad and was no longer meeting his standards. He blockouts new routes (stairs, vines, recovery paths) and explicitly delays aesthetics/UV work until movement feels fun and readable.
key_stories.challenge: An earlier design (leaf/ride segment) created an unfun or overly annoying traversal experience for a relatively early course.
key_stories.process: He replaces the segment with a “platforming playground,” adds stair exits from water, tests jump lines, adjusts collision/layout, and only then plans to UV-map and settle the art style.
key_stories.outcome: The area’s new traversal direction is established; remaining tasks include adding the Yoshi-god statue setpiece and then moving on to visual polish/UV mapping.
key_stories.key_quote: Right now we just want the platforming to be fun. And then we can think about the visuals.

key_stories.title: Water can still crash the game due to outdated movement/step logic
key_stories.summary: While iterating on the temple area, Kaze flags that water interactions remain dangerous to test because the water system hasn’t been updated to the project’s newer step-function logic. This creates a real crash risk and affects how confidently he can iterate on water-adjacent platforming.
key_stories.challenge: Legacy water behavior depends on older step functions that the project no longer fully supports, causing instability.
key_stories.process: Kaze avoids unnecessary water contact during tests and treats crashes/loading weirdness as symptoms to be addressed later when water is migrated to the new movement pipeline.
key_stories.outcome: The issue remains open, shaping short-term level-design decisions (safer exits, minimizing forced water time) until the underlying water-step migration is completed.
key_stories.key_quote: Being in water can just crash the game.

key_stories.title: Decomp workflow forces all level areas to load at once (RAM + loading-time cost)
key_stories.summary: Kaze explains a structural drawback of decomp-based development compared with older binary-hack tooling: RoamManager-style area streaming isn’t readily available. As a result, areas currently load together, consuming extra RAM and contributing to long loads, unless he learns linker scripting to implement a decomp-compatible solution.
key_stories.challenge: Long loading times and RAM pressure, especially in multi-area levels, with limited existing tooling in the decomp environment.
key_stories.process: He describes the missing tool (RoamManager), why it doesn’t apply to decomp, and the technical barrier (linker scripts) required to restore per-area loading.
key_stories.outcome: For now, he accepts the all-at-once loading approach, while acknowledging a potential future engineering task to reclaim RAM and reduce load times.
key_stories.key_quote: If you wanted to load the areas one by one, you need to learn a lot of linker script that I haven’t learned yet.

open_questions.context: Kaze says Course 13’s theme is set (suspenseful ice castle) but he still needs a boss and invites brainstorming.
questions: What role is the Ice Castle boss supposed to play in the game’s pacing—skill check, narrative beat, or mechanical twist?
What boss ideas were considered and rejected, and what constraints (N64 performance, camera, arena size, animation budget) are shaping the final choice?
How do you decide whether an RTYI boss should feel “Mario 64-authentic” versus more experimental/modern?

open_questions.topic: Fixing water crashes by migrating to the new step function
open_questions.context: Kaze warns that water can crash because it hasn’t been updated to the new step-function system and old step functions aren’t fully supported.
questions: What changed in the project’s step-function system, and why does water still rely on legacy behavior?
How often do crashes occur in practice, and what kinds of bugs do they produce (hard crash, softlock, physics corruption)?
What would it take to complete the water migration—what’s the engineering plan and what has blocked it so far?

open_questions.topic: Restoring per-area level loading in decomp (linker-script barrier)
open_questions.context: Kaze explains that decomp can’t easily use RoamManager and that implementing per-area loading would require linker-script knowledge he hasn’t learned yet.
questions: How big of a RAM/loading-time win would per-area loading be for RTYI—are there specific courses where it becomes critical?
Have you considered asking a specialist (or community contributor) to help with linker scripts, and what would collaboration on that look like?
How does the all-at-once loading constraint affect level design decisions (area count, setpiece size, texture budgets)?
